Si un personnage capable de lancer des sorts réussit ensuite trois tests d'Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) DC 15 consécutifs tout en touchant continuellement le mur, les liens sont supprimés suffisamment longtemps pour que l'élémentaire puisse quitter la pièce. Un sort de {@spell dispel magic} lancé sur les runes supprime les liens pendant 1 minute.

L'élémentaire suit son sauveteur et se bat à ses côtés. Si l'élémentaire voit la faille dans {@adventure area 7|TftYP-DiT|1|7. Chaos Rift}, il utilise la faille pour quitter le Doomvault et retourner sur le plan élémentaire du feu.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: Une porte blanche se trouve à l'est de cette zone, à la jonction des couloirs qui mènent à la porte abyssale et aux salles des vermines.

entries.name: 7. Chaos Rift
entries: Les personnages qui s'approchent de cette zone peuvent entendre le rugissement de la faille élémentaire, qui génère également une lumière vive dans toute la chambre.

Cette énorme salle est ornée de rangées de piliers sculptés en forme de créatures élémentaires et démoniaques. Une grande brèche a été ouverte au centre du sol en pierre. A travers elle, un flux d'énergie chaotique se propage vers le haut, se déversant dans une faille similaire dans le plafond voûté quarante pieds au-dessus. Des vrilles se détachent de la colonne d'énergie pulsée, s'élançant pour frapper les piliers les plus proches.
Dans le coin sud-ouest, il y a une porte noire.

Un personnage qui réussit un test d'Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) DC 10 peut dire que la faille canalise des forces élémentaires. Si le test est réussi par 5 ou plus, le personnage sait que la faille est dangereuse et qu'elle canalise des forces élémentaires extraplanaires.

Si une créature non élémentaire termine son tour à l'intérieur de la pièce, elle subit 5 ({@dice 2d4}) dégâts d'un type aléatoire (lancez un {@dice d10} : 1-2, acide ; 3-4, froid ; 5-6, feu ; 7-8, foudre ; 9-10, tonnerre).

Toute créature qui entre dans la faille peut choisir d'y rester ou de se rendre dans un plan élémentaire. Les personnages qui vont dans un plan élémentaire doivent utiliser la faille pour revenir à leur prochain tour ou ils deviennent piégés.

entries.name: Abyssal Gate
entries: {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP} supervise cette zone, dans laquelle les Thayans ont exploité la puissance abyssale.

entries.name: 8. Summoning Chamber
entries: Un personnage qui écoute aux portes peut entendre les cris de tous les démons liés ici.

Cette zone aurait pu être autrefois une grande salle de banquet, mais son mobilier gît maintenant en piles pourries le long des murs. Entre les rangées de piliers, six grands cercles magiques brillent de mille feux, éclairant toute la pièce.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Un {@creature dread warrior|TftYP}, deux {@creature Wight||wights} et six {@creature Zombie||zombies} patrouillent dans la zone.

entries.name: Summoning Circles
entries: Deux cercles d'invocation sont vides. Les quatre autres contiennent des créatures :
{@b Circle A}. Un {@creature reduced-threat hezrou|TftYP} (voir "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" ci-dessus)
{@b Circle B}. Four {@creature Quasit||quasits}
{@b Circle C}. Un {@creature reduced-threat vrock|TftYP} (voir "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" ci-dessus)
{@b Circle D}. Ten {@creature manes}

Un démon lié ne peut pas s'échapper de son cercle sans aide, et à part les tentatives de communication, rien de ce qu'il fait ne peut affecter quoi que ce soit en dehors du cercle. Tous les démons, à l'exception des crinières, demandent à être libérés, promettant d'attaquer les forces thayennes s'ils sont libérés. En réussissant un test d'Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) DC 10, un personnage sait que, comme action, il peut érafler la limite d'un cercle pour perturber la magie du cercle pendant 1 minute. Pendant ce temps, un démon à l'intérieur du cercle peut se libérer en réussissant un test de Sagesse DC 15.
Un démon libéré attaque la créature la plus proche qui n'est pas un démon.

entries.name: Development
entries: Si un démon autre que les crinières reste libre dans cette zone, tous les démons sont finalement libérés de leur cercle par les autres. Ils se répandent dans la zone et attaquent toute créature qu'ils trouvent. Ce fait doit être noté comme faisant partie de l'état du donjon.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: Une porte blanche se trouve au nord de cette zone, à la jonction des couloirs qui mènent au Temple du Chaos et aux Salles des Vermines. Une autre porte se trouve dans le passage à l'est qui communique avec le Parcours des porcs.
Un ensemble de doubles portes est incrusté de filigrane en laiton, marquant les formes de figures angéliques.

entries.name: Advance Notice
entries: Un personnage qui fouille le sol du couloir est et réussit un test d'Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) ou de Sagesse ({@skill Survival}) DC 15 constate qu'aucune autre créature n'est entrée dans ce passage latéral depuis longtemps.
Si elle est examinée avec un sort {@spell detect magic}, la zone affiche une aura de nécromancie.

entries.name: Stunning Shadow Trap
entries: Si les portes sont ouvertes, faites un jet d'initiative. L'obscurité envahit immédiatement le couloir jusqu'à 6 mètres des portes. Toute créature non-morte qui commence son tour dans la zone doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Charisme DC 15 ou subir 7 ({@dice 2d6}) dégâts nécrotiques et devenir {@condition paralyzed} jusqu'au début de son prochain tour. L'obscurité demeure tant que les portes sont ouvertes.
Des tapisseries tapissent les murs de ces quartiers d'habitation bien aménagés. Des écrans sur pied divisent l'espace en sections plus petites contenant des canapés, des tables et des bureaux.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Ici réside la liche {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP} avec ses gardes, quatre {@creature Dread Warrior|TftYP|dread warriors}. Ayant perdu la Porte du sang, Var est confiné dans cette zone à cause de sa peur de Szass Tam, en attendant le jugement final de son maître.

La liche attaque immédiatement. Ses gardes émergent de diverses positions pour le protéger d'une attaque directe. {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP} peut lancer n'importe lequel de ses sorts depuis l'un des guerriers redoutables.

Les guerriers de l'épouvante tentent de traîner les personnages sans défense vers la fosse de l'intersection près de cette pièce ou vers {@adventure area 9|TftYP-DiT|1|9. Dead End}, où ils ouvrent les portes.
Sournois et arrogant, {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP} pense que toutes les autres créatures sont inférieures à lui. Il réprimande les personnages à chaque occasion et pousse ses subordonnés à la cruauté.

S'il est réduit à 30 points de vie ou moins, Var offre au groupe l'accès aux accords de sa clé glyphique et de sa clé d'acier (voir "Trésor" ci-dessous), ainsi que deux morceaux de savoir, en échange de sa liberté et de son silence. Si les personnages laissent Var partir, il fuit la voûte céleste, pensant que les perturbations des personnages attireront l'attention de Szass Tam loin de lui. Si la liche est détruite ici, elle pourrait être détruite définitivement plus tard si le groupe réussit à faire s'effondrer la voûte des phylactères.

entries.name: Contact Stone
entries: Un cercle de glyphes lumineux au-dessus du bureau de Var, dans la partie ouest de la pièce, sert de pierre de contact.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Une fouille du bureau révèle plusieurs brouillons d'une lettre à Szass Tam dans laquelle Var supplie qu'on lui donne une autre chance de soumettre la Côte des Épées à la domination thaïlandaise. Dans les différents tiroirs du bureau se trouvent un {@item potion of mind reading} et un double de la clé en acier que Var porte sur lui.

Le plus grand tiroir du bureau est maintenu fermé par un sort {@spell arcane lock} (nécessitant un test de Force DC 25 réussi pour le casser). À l'intérieur se trouve une boîte plate en bois noir (voir la sous-section suivante) et un coffret en or forgé pour ressembler à un dragon endormi aux yeux grenat violet (d'une valeur de 1 000 gp). Le coffret contient 200 gp et une pierre de rivière sombre et lisse (un {@item loadstone|TftYP}).

entries.name: True Name Box
entries: Si {@spell detect magic} est utilisé sur la boîte noire, son contenu dégage une aura de magie d'évocation. La boîte contient plusieurs morceaux de parchemin. Une partie de la page supérieure stockée dans la boîte porte des runes qui, lorsqu'elles sont lues par quelqu'un d'autre que {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP}, font exploser la page.

Les runes peuvent être neutralisées en utilisant {@spell dispel magic} sur la boîte ou la page. Sinon, un personnage qui réussit un test d'Intelligence DC 10 peut retirer la page de la boîte sans lire les runes par inadvertance. Si le test échoue, le personnage lit les runes par inadvertance, ce qui déclenche l'explosion.

Si la page explose, toute personne se trouvant dans un rayon de 3 mètres autour de la boîte doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Dextérité DC 15, que le lecteur réussit avec un désavantage. Une créature subit 21 ({@dice 6d6}) dégâts de force sur un jet de sauvegarde raté et moitié moins de dégâts sur un jet réussi. La boîte et son contenu sont détruits si les runes s'éteignent.

La boîte contient des enregistrements des vrais noms de démons mineurs et décrit les plans pour les utiliser dans l'attaque de la Côte des Épées. Elle contient également des documents historiques qui indiquent que Var était à la recherche du vrai nom d'un démon de fosse appelé Baazka.

entries.name: Keys
entries: {@creature Tarul Var|TftYP} porte une clé glyphe accordée à cette zone et aux Temples de l'Angoisse (dans le secteur des Temples de l'Extraction). Il possède également une clé en acier ornée (d'une valeur de 5 gp) qui ouvre les portes verrouillées sur le mur est de {@adventure area 4|TftYP-DiT|1|4. Mystic Circles}.

entries.name: 11. Torture Chamber
entries: Un personnage qui écoute aux portes peut entendre les hurlements du glabrezu s'il est lié ici.

Les murs de cette chambre de torture sont suspendus à des chaînes et des lances incrustées d'ichor noir. A quelques endroits, de lourdes chaînes noires sont attachées au sol. Dans le coin nord-est se trouve une porte noire.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Un {@creature wight} et sept {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} tourmentent un {@condition prone}, {@creature reduced-threat glabrezu|TftYP} (voir "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" ci-dessus) qui est entravé et enchaîné au sol à quatre endroits. Les morts-vivants attaquent les intrus, utilisant des piques comme armes ({@dice 1d10} de dégâts perforants). Les morts-vivants disposent d'armes magiques (voir "Trésor" ci-dessous).

entries.name: Shackled Glabrezu
entries: Le glabrezu lié ne peut pas se libérer. Il ne peut pas lancer de sorts ou invoquer des démons. Il ne peut attaquer que si une créature s'approche de lui à moins d'un mètre cinquante, ce qui explique pourquoi les morts-vivants utilisent des piques. Lorsqu'une bataille s'engage, le démon exige d'être libéré, promettant de "dévaster ces morts-vivants et leurs maîtres". Si les personnages refusent de l'aider, le démon les attaque s'il le peut.

Pour libérer le démon, un personnage doit crocheter les serrures des quatre entraves en fer (en réussissant un test de Dextérité DC 15 pour chacune d'elles). S'il est libéré, le glabrezu se déchaîne, attaquant au hasard toute personne à sa portée. Une fois libre, il peut lancer des sorts, mais il ne peut toujours pas invoquer de démons.

entries.name: Shackles
entries: Les dix jeux d'entraves et leurs chaînes sont faits de fer inscrit dans une rune. Un démon qui y est retenu ne peut s'en échapper tant que les chaînes sont fermées. La magie sur les chaînes les rend incassables, elles ne peuvent donc pas être retirées de cette pièce.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: Si le glabrezu est laissé libre dans cette zone, il finit par libérer les démons en {@adventure area 8|TftYP-DiT|1|8. Summoning Chamber} de leurs cercles. Ce fait doit être noté comme faisant partie de l'état du donjon.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Les piques des squelettes sont enchantées avec {@spell magic weapon} (+1) pendant 1 heure de plus. Le sorcier brandit un {@item +1 pike}.

entries.name: Halls of Conditioning
entries: Après leur soumission initiale, les démons capturés sont détenus dans les Halls de conditionnement, où ils sont correctement brisés pour servir.

entries.name: 12. False Pit Gauntlet
entries: Communiquez le texte encadré avant qu'un personnage ne franchisse le seuil de cette pièce.

Ici, les murs sont en pierre travaillée, mais le plafond de trente pieds de haut de cette large chambre est constitué de roches brutes accrochées à des stalactites déchiquetées. Les joints des dalles de sol divisent l'espace en carrés d'un mètre cinquante de côté. Une fosse ouverte s'étend à mi-chemin de chacune des quatre entrées, juste à l'intérieur de la pièce.

entries.name: Aura
entries: Un sort {@spell detect magic} lancé sur cette zone révèle que la magie imprègne toute la pièce, se concentrant plus fortement sur la bouche ouverte de chaque fosse.

entries.name: False Pits
entries: Les fosses semblent normales, mais un champ de force invisible s'étend sur l'espace apparemment ouvert au sommet de chaque fosse. Le champ horizontal peut supporter le poids d'un nombre quelconque de personnages.

entries.name: Gravity Trap
entries: Toute créature qui entre dans la pièce et traverse le champ invisible couvrant l'une des fosses ouvertes désactive le piège à gravité pendant 1 minute. Une fois désactivé, les personnages peuvent se déplacer librement dans la pièce pendant 1 minute avant que le piège ne se réactive. Si le piège est actif, toute créature qui entre dans la pièce sans marcher sur le champ invisible recouvrant l'une des fausses fosses est projetée vers le plafond, subissant 10 ({@dice 3d6}) de dégâts perforants de la part des stalactites et restant {@condition restrained} au plafond pendant 1 minute. Puis la créature est relâchée et tombe sur le sol, subissant 10 ({@dice 3d6}) de dégâts de chute et atterrissant {@condition prone} dans un carré aléatoire près du centre de la chambre. Se déplacer sur ou au-dessus du sol déclenche à nouveau le piège à gravité, mais la créature peut rester en sécurité si elle reste dans l'espace où elle est tombée jusqu'à ce qu'un autre personnage désactive le piège.

entries.name: 13. Sorlan's Haunt
entries: La serrure bien visible sur chacune des portes doubles est fausse. Les vraies serrures et les trous de serrure sont cachés à la base de chaque porte et peuvent être détectés avec un test de Sagesse ({@skill Perception}) DC 15 réussi. Si l'on tente de crocheter une fausse serrure ou de forcer les portes, toute créature située à moins de 3 mètres des portes doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution DC 14 (avec désavantage, si l'on tente de crocheter une serrure ou de forcer les portes) ou subir 5 ({@dice 2d4}) dégâts de force et être assommée {@condition prone}.

This ruined chamber has tapestries and paintings that have been slashed and are shot through with black mold. The fine furnishings and cushions are rotted through and crumbling, and the air is heavy with the scent of decay.

entries.name: Creature
entries: Sorlan, a former adventurer who was imprisoned by the Red Wizards and subjected to horrible experiments, lives on as a {@creature ghost} that is bound to this room. He hates the Red Wizards, and he immediately tries to attack all who enter his chamber, screaming that allies of the Red Wizards must die. If the characters convince Sorlan that they are opposed to the Red Wizards by making a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, the ghost stops attacking and can provide two pieces of lore, which he has overheard from passing Red Wizards.

Sorlan also tells the characters to avoid the maze of undoing ({@adventure area 15|TftYP-DiT|1|15. Maze of Undoing}), which is where he was captured while trying to escape the dungeon. He doesn't know the trick to overcoming the teleportation trap. If he is slain, Sorlan reappears in this {@adventure area 24|TftYP-DiT|1|24. Pale Garden} hours later.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: The secret door on the west wall opens into a narrow corridor that leads to a white gate. Beyond the gate (and another secret door) is a corridor that connects with the Pools of Devotion.

Several cages line this chamber from floor to ceiling. Three of them hold various demons, which are raging futilely and silently against their confinement. The wall in the southwest corner contains a contact stone.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One Red Wizard {@creature conjurer|VGM} oversees one {@creature deathlock wight|MTF} and one {@creature Thayan apprentice|TftYP}. The conjurer knows the pass phrase for the maze of undoing ({@adventure area 15|TftYP-DiT|1|15. Maze of Undoing}) and might provide it to the characters in exchange for mercy, knowing that freed demons will attack their "rescuers."

entries.name: Cells
entries: Cells that confine demons hold the following creatures:
{@b Cell A}. One {@creature hezrou}
{@b Cell B}. Eight {@creature Quasit||quasits}
{@b Cell C}. Two {@creature Vrock||vrocks}

Each cell has iron, rune-scribed bars (warded against demons). Transmutation magic on the bars renders them unbreakable, so a demon can't escape the cell and, indeed, can't pass any part of its body between the bars. Further, no sound can pass out of a cell into the larger room. To free a demon, a character must pick the lock on the cage door (requiring a successful DC 20 Dexterity check). A freed demon attacks everyone in the room.

entries.name: Keys
entries: The Red Wizard has a glyph key attuned to this zone, as well as a ring of keys to the cells.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: If any demon remains free in this area, all the demons are eventually freed from their cells. That fact should be noted as part of the dungeon state.

A short hall of gray granite runs perpendicular to this area's entrance, with six openings across from the entrance that lead deeper into the darkness. The cold stone ceiling looms thirty feet overhead.

entries.name: Teleportation Maze
entries: Conjuration magic infuses the area, emanating most strongly at the trigger points numbered 1 through 20, and at the two entry/exit trigger points labeled E on the map. In addition to the teleportation trigger points, the magic aligns gravity to the nearest surface. Therefore, creatures standing on the floor consider "down" to be beneath their feet, while creatures on the ceiling consider that surface to be "down" and are situated accordingly. The entire area was created to capture and hold demons.

Any creature that enters a trigger point on the floor teleports immediately to the ceiling above another trigger point (determined by a {@dice d20} roll). The creature must then succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or take 5 ({@dice 2d4}) psychic damage and fall to the floor, taking 10 ({@dice 3d6}) falling damage and triggering another teleportation point. On a successful save, the creature takes no damage and can utilize the weird gravity until the end of its next turn, walking along the ceiling and walls as though they were the floor, and bypassing the teleportation triggers. If the creature is still above the floor at the end of its next turn, it falls the appropriate distance to the floor and triggers another teleportation point.

In addition to conjuration magic, the entry/exit points also radiate abjuration magic. Until someone utters the proper pass phrase (see {@adventure area 14|TftYP-DiT|1|14. Demon Cells}), a demon caught in the maze can't pass through either of the entry/exit points. For non-demons, leaving the maze can be accomplished by moving along the walls or ceiling and out of the area through either entry/exit point.

entries.name: Creature
entries: When the characters arrive, a {@creature glabrezu} is trapped in the maze. The demon has learned how to navigate the maze, even though it can't escape the area. Place the demon on the ceiling above a random teleportation trigger point in the maze (roll a {@dice d20}). Once the demon notices the characters, it moves toward characters it can see and in its rage and madness attacks any creatures it manages to reach.

entries.name: Black Gate
entries: A black gate is set into the southern alcove, not immediately visible from the entrance.

entries.name: Blood Pens
entries: The Red Wizards are breeding and raising monsters in their own foul nurseries.
Locations in the Blood Pens are identified on map 5.4.

entries.name: Vermin Halls
entries: The vermin-summoning magic of these halls now serves the Thayans.

entries.name: 16. Gallery of Swarms
entries: The Red Wizards no longer use this chamber.

entries.name: Sounds
entries: A character who listens at the door and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check hears distant chittering.

The sunken floor of this huge hall is covered in dead insects, their dried shells shifting and whispering in a faint breeze. Dozens of demonic faces are carved in the white marble walls of the chamber, slight gusts whistling from each of their open mouths. Down the center of the chamber, toward the doors at the far end, a series of black stone platforms are set like oversized stepping stones.

entries.name: Demonic Faces
entries: The mouths of these relief carvings are the source of the magical breeze.

entries.name: Insect Floor
entries: The floor is 2 feet below the level of the doors and filled completely with dead insects along with occasional bones, making it {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Pit Traps
entries: Scattered through the room, hidden beneath the blanket of insect bodies, are several pit traps. It is impossible to notice a pit passively; finding one requires a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Each pit is filled with dead insects, so falling into one deals only half damage. Someone buried in a pit full of these husks can't breathe or see.

entries.name: Trapped Platforms
entries: Whenever a creature steps onto a platform, it must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or be engulfed by a swarm of biting, stinging insects that emerge from the demonic faces. The creature takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) piercing damage and 5 ({@dice 2d4}) poison damage, and must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or fall off the platform in a random direction. The insects die and fall to the ground immediately after their attack.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: A white gate is located west of this area at the junction of the corridors that lead to the Temple of Chaos and to the Abyssal Gate.

Two enormous pillars on the far side of this chamber emit brilliant white light that holds the attention of dozens of giant vermin crawling on and around them. The vermin occasionally fight among themselves, but most of these creatures move sluggishly, as if the light has subdued them.

entries.name: Glowing Pillars
entries: The pillars emit magical light, which pacifies the vermin and keeps their handlers safe.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature Thayan Apprentice|TftYP|Thayan apprentices} are feeding the vermin scraps and pig excrement from buckets. Six {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} guard the apprentices. All the Thayans attack as soon as they notice intruders. Each round of combat, the Thayans direct one {@creature giant spider} and one {@creature giant centipede} to join the fight.

entries.name: Development
entries: Vermin left in this chamber grow hungry, feeding on any dead creatures. Within a few hours, they begin killing and feeding on each other.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: One Thayan has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: A white gate is located in the south branch of the corridor that leads east from this area toward the Swine Run.

Rough cots scattered across the floor contrast with the decor in the east end of the room, which contains a great seat of white marble. Some of the magic lights are shrouded, so that side of the room is dimly lit.
In the northeast corner is a black gate. West of it is a contact stone.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Six {@creature Thayan Apprentice|TftYP|Thayan apprentices} and eight {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} are resting here, watched over by a {@creature wight}. Half the warriors and apprentices are asleep in the eastern side of the chamber. When the other creatures notice the characters, they attack. The sleeping Thayans awaken and join the fight over the course of 2 or 3 rounds.

entries.name: Throne Swarm Trap
entries: The 20-foot-tall white throne is a magic trap that the Thayans might use if desperate. When any non-undead creature climbs onto it, a swarm of stinging insects pours out of the back of the throne and quickly fills the chamber. Each creature in the room takes 9 ({@dice 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@dice 2d8}) poison damage. For 1 minute thereafter, each creature that ends its turn in the room takes 4 ({@dice 1d8}) piercing damage and 4 ({@dice 1d8}) poison damage. The insects disappear after 1 minute, and the trap resets.

entries.name: Glyph Keys
entries: One Thayan has a glyph key attuned to this zone and the Swine Run. Another has a glyph key attuned to this zone and the Hatchery.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: A white gate is located in the south branch of the corridor that leads west from this area toward the Swine Run.

entries.name: Swine Run
entries: These adjoining halls have been converted into a pig farm to feed carnivorous monsters.

entries.name: Sounds
entries: The unmistakable squealing and grunting of pigs can be heard from outside any of the entrances.

entries.name: Blocked Stairs
entries: Slabs of stone, each 5 feet high, block the stairs that descend into this hall along the north and east sides. Climbing over a slab costs 10 feet of movement. Once over a slab, a character can step onto a plank bridge (see below).
Knocking a slab down requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. If a slab is knocked down, the bridge collapses and packs of pigs rush into the open area (see "Pigpens" below).

What once must have been a great hall is now a great swine pen. Three rows of thick pillars support the ceiling. Each pillar is marked with a large X in red paint. Pigs, perhaps hundreds of them, are packed in here, shoulder to shoulder, on the floor. Ten feet above them, skeletal undead stand on a crude bridge of wooden planks, dumping food into the pigpen.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature Deathlock Wight|MTF|deathlock wights} oversee six {@creature Skeleton||skeletons}. They attack intruders.

entries.name: Aura
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a transmutation aura on the whole area, which is a simple magical effect to control the pigs' odor.

entries.name: Bridges
entries: A series of unsteady plank bridges runs 10 feet above the floor, lashed to the pillars and to the slabs of rock that block the eastern stairs. Any creature that falls {@condition unconscious} while on a bridge has a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance to fall into the pigpen.

entries.name: Enchanted Pillars
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that each pillar radiates an aura of enchantment magic. Any humanoid that touches a pillar must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. (The Thayans marked the pillars as a reminder for themselves.) A {@spell dispel magic} spell suppresses the magic of the pillars for 1 minute.

entries.name: Floating Disk
entries: An opaque, slightly concave, circular plane of magical force, 5 feet in diameter, floats on the northern side of the northern bridge to {@adventure area 20|TftYP-DiT|1|20. Abattoir}. The disk can hold up to 1,000 pounds. It is stationary and level with the bridge, but it can be mentally directed by anyone who can see it (DC 10 Intelligence) to float to the blocked stairway that leads up to the Vermin Halls (areas 16–18).

entries.name: Pigpens
entries: The pigs are maltreated, hungry, and irritated. They swarm any creature that enters the pen. Such a creature must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw at the start of each of its turns or take 3 ({@dice 1d6}) bludgeoning damage and 3 ({@dice 1d6}) piercing damage. Characters who take 12 damage also are knocked {@condition prone}. Single-target attacks against the pigs have little effect, but an area spell clears its area of pigs until the end of the caster's next turn.
The enclosed area beneath the bridge is filled with sows and piglets. The DC for the Dexterity saving throw here is only 8.

entries.name: Drevin
entries: One pig is much smaller than the others, and looks especially malnourished. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that the creature radiates transmutation magic. The pig is in fact a lightfoot halfling named {@creature Drevin|TftYP}. He was a minstrel (use the {@creature spy} statistics) who ran afoul of a Red Wizard {@creature transmuter|VGM}. If freed of the {@spell true polymorph} spell he is under, {@creature Drevin|TftYP} accompanies the characters until he is permitted to escape the Doomvault, at which point he departs amid promises to write great ballads about the characters' exploits.

entries.name: Glyph Keys
entries: Each wight has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: 20. Abattoir

entries: Empty wall niches might once have held works of art, but this broad gallery has now been converted to an abattoir, its floor slick with filth and gore.
In the southeast corner is a black gate. North of the gate is a contact stone.

If the pigs from {@adventure area 19|TftYP-DiT|1|19. Walkway Pen} rush into this room, they move unwittingly toward the skeletons, knocking half of them {@condition prone} before retreating back into the pigpen.

entries.name: Aura
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a faint aura of transmutation magic on the whole area, which is a simple magical effect to control the odor of the butchery.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Twelve {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} are here, with a {@creature wight} and a {@creature deathlock wight|MTF} overseeing them. Eight work to the east, stacking butchered pigs along the wall. To the west, four more work at a sluice that carries offal to the black gate, where it disappears (transported to {@adventure area 41|TftYP-DiT|1|41. Garbage Transfer}). Occasionally they toss some of the foul slop toward an {@creature otyugh} chained to the floor.

The otyugh can move 40 feet from the northeast corner, anywhere within the area described by the dashed line on the map. It attacks any creature it can reach. If it can't attack, the otyugh uses its turn to attempt a DC 20 Strength check to break its chain while its captors are distracted.

With its childlike intellect and telepathy, the otyugh broadcasts its desire for more food. The characters are able to communicate with the creature, and if they offer to feed it, the otyugh ceases attacking for 1 round. Then the characters must periodically placate it with successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks. A character who frees the otyugh learns that more of its kind are in the dungeon and receives a general impression of {@adventure area 42|TftYP-DiT|1|42. Otyugh Lair}, where more otyughs live. All these otyughs hate the Thayans.

entries.name: Niches
entries: The shallow niches are 3 feet off the floor and 5 feet high. Climbing into a niche costs 10 feet of movement.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: If the otyugh is given a glyph key to the Prison of Filth and told how to use a black gate, it teleports to {@adventure area 41|TftYP-DiT|1|41. Garbage Transfer} and reaches {@adventure area 42|TftYP-DiT|1|42. Otyugh Lair}. Its presence there will change the characters' encounter with the other otyughs (see {@adventure area 42|TftYP-DiT|1|42. Otyugh Lair}).

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: The wight has a glyph key attuned to this zone and the Prison of Filth.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: The corridor that leads east to {@adventure area 22|TftYP-DiT|1|22. Hatchling Pens} in the Hatchery contains a white gate. Another white gate is situated in the southern passage that connects with {@adventure area 21|TftYP-DiT|1|21. Egg Chamber} in the Hatchery.

entries.name: Hatchery
entries: Thayans tend and hatch the eggs of exotic monsters in these areas, rearing the young to serve Thay.

entries.name: 21. Egg Chamber
entries: The two approaches to this area are warm and humid.

Heat wafts from this chamber, and steam obscures parts of the room. Stone braziers built into the walls burn with orange flame, as do braziers in various places across the room. The floor is covered with sand, on which rest dozens of large eggs of various colors and textures.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A Red Wizard {@creature enchanter|VGM}, one {@creature dread warrior|TftYP}, and six {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} oversee the eggs. If combat breaks out, the wizard sends the undead forward as a screen and uses targeted spells that won't harm the eggs.

entries.name: Braziers
entries: The magic stone braziers are built into the room and can't be moved. A creature that touches a brazier for the first time on a turn takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) fire damage.

entries.name: Eggs
entries: Clusters of eggs make this area {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. None of the eggs is close to hatching. One person with a weapon could destroy all the eggs in about 5 minutes. Leaving the eggs untended also renders them lifeless. The eggs are those of an assortment of creatures, including hook horrors, remorhazes, wyverns, and basilisks, with {@dice 1d6 + 1} of each kind. Identifying a particular kind of egg requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check.

entries.name: Steam
entries: Steam renders this chamber lightly obscured.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: The Red Wizard has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: In the corridor beyond the western exit is a white gate that separates {@adventure area 21|TftYP-DiT|1|21. Egg Chamber} from the Swine Run.

entries.name: 22. Hatchling Pens
entries: Anyone near the doors hears the shrieking and howling of the caged creatures.
Relief carvings of angelic figures along the walls of this huge hall contrast with the crowded iron cages here. Half of these cells are packed with miniature, shrieking versions of deadly monsters.
In the southeast corner is a black gate. North of the gate is a contact stone.

entries.name: Aura
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a transmutation aura on the whole area, which is a simple magical effect to control the odor of the hatchlings and their food.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A Red Wizard {@creature transmuter|VGM} oversees two {@creature Thayan Apprentice|TftYP|Thayan apprentices} in caring for the imprisoned hatchlings, while four {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} stand guard. They attack intruders. In a desperate battle, the Red Wizard might take the time to release hatchlings to add to the characters' opposition.

If the battle goes badly for the Thayans, the Red Wizard surrenders. Her name is Myrja, and her allegiance to Szass Tam is less than resolute. If the characters spare her, she offers the pass phrase to get by the trap and creatures in {@adventure area 23|TftYP-DiT|1|23. Dead Garden} ("That which is dead, stay so") and one piece of lore.

entries.name: Cages
entries: Half the cages here are empty. The others hold the following young monsters, which are reduced-threat creatures (see "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" above):
{@b Cage A}. One {@creature Reduced-Threat Remorhaz|TftYP|remorhaz}
{@b Cage B}. Two {@creature Reduced-Threat Basilisk|TftYP|basilisks}
{@b Cage C}. Five {@creature Reduced-Threat Darkmantle|TftYP|darkmantles}
{@b Cage D}. Five {@creature Reduced-Threat Ettercap|TftYP|ettercaps}
{@b Cage E}. Two {@creature Reduced-Threat Carrion Crawler|TftYP|carrion crawlers}
{@b Cage F}. One {@creature Reduced-Threat Behir|TftYP|behir} (no Constrict or Swallow traits)
{@b Cage G}. Two {@creature Reduced-Threat Hook Horror|TftYP|hook horrors}
{@b Cage H}. One {@creature Reduced-Threat Wyvern|TftYP|wyvern}

Each cage has rune-scribed bars of steel. Transmutation magic on the bars renders them unbreakable, so a creature inside can't physically or magically attack through the bars. To free the occupants of a cage, a character can pick the lock on the cage door, which requires a successful DC 15 Dexterity check.
If freed from their cages, the young attack the nearest creatures. If a Thayan and a character are equally close to a young creature, it targets the character.

entries.name: Keys
entries: Myrja has a glyph key attuned to this zone. She also carries a key to each of the cages in a ring on her belt.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: Area 22 is bordered by three white gates. One connects to the Swine Run, another to the Dark Gardens, and a third to the Temples of Despair.

entries.name: Dark Gardens
entries: Once an area of deadly gardens, these chambers have been altered to support the Blood Pens.
Dead and blackened thorny vines cover the walls and floor, which are peppered with small, circular holes the size of a human fist.
In the northeast corner is a black gate.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Seven {@creature Zombie||zombies} and two {@creature Wight||wights} are focused on the doors to areas 22 and 24. Those who appear by way of the black gate can gain surprise if they attack immediately.

Unless the creatures are attacked, they grant free passage to anyone who appears to be a Thayan and knows the room's pass phrase (see {@adventure area 22|TftYP-DiT|1|22. Hatchling Pens}). The wights challenge those who know the phrase but look like intruders. It takes a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}) check to convince the wights to stand down.

entries.name: Aura
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell cast on this area reveals an aura of transmutation magic around each hole, hinting at the presence of a magical effect.

entries.name: Blood Vines Trap
entries: If a non-undead creature moves 10 feet or farther into the room without uttering the pass phrase, animated vines shoot out of the holes and into every part of the room. Each creature must say the phrase; it's not good enough for one character to say it for the whole group.

The vines ignore the undead. Any non-undead creature in the room when the vines emerge must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition restrained} by a vine. A creature takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) piercing damage each time it starts its turn {@condition restrained} in this way. As an action, a {@condition restrained} creature can free itself or another creature with a successful DC 13 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, or free only itself with a successful DC 13 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. A vine that's restraining a creature can also be cut and killed; each vine has AC 15 and 8 hit points.

While the vines are present, the area is lightly obscured and {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. A creature takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) piercing damage for every 5 feet it moves through the room. A creature that moves more than 15 feet on its turn must immediately make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes {@condition restrained} as described above.
If no creature is {@condition restrained} at the end of a round after the trap has been triggered, all the vines immediately die. The trap then goes dormant for 1 hour.

entries.name: Glyph Keys
entries: Each of the wights has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: A white gate is located in the corridor to the west between this area and the Hatchery.

entries.name: 24. Pale Garden
entries: The Red Wizards use this magical garden for food.

entries.name: Light
entries: The room is filled with dim light.

The scent of decaying plants hangs over an underground garden. White vines, trembling as if touched by an unfelt breeze, twine around cracked pillars that glow with pale light. Between the pillars, ashen flowers, sickly gray shrubs, and giant mushrooms stand in dense groves around a couple of gravel paths.
Many baskets full of plant matter are stacked on shelves carved into the walls near the doors.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Twelve unarmed humanoid {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} wander the area, harvesting plant material in large baskets. As they tear off growths, a crackling sound accompanies an increase in the glow of a nearby pillar, and the harvested plant starts to rapidly regrow.
The skeletons ignore intruders unless they are attacked or damaged, in which case they all attack trespassers in the room.

Two {@creature Shambling Mound||shambling mounds} hide in the groves, ignoring the skeletons. These creatures are trained to disregard anyone who remains within 15 feet of any doorway, where the baskets are stored on the shelves. They wait to ambush any non-undead creature that ventures any farther into the room.

entries.name: Dense Garden
entries: Any area within 5 feet of a pillar and not shown on the map as part of the path is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Pillars
entries: The chamber's pillars respond when plant matter in the chamber is damaged. At the end of each round during which a shambling mound took damage, a discharge of energy ripples over the pillars, and each creature within 5 feet of a pillar takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) lightning damage.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: The passage that leads west contains a white gate that connects with the Temples of Despair.

A garden courtyard fit for a palace features walls of dark marble veined with gray. The ceiling of brass is supported on black marble pillars. Between the pillars, raised stone garden beds are filled with flowers and creeping vines in every color of the rainbow, their sweet scent hanging in the air.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Thuria, a Red Wizard {@creature enchanter|VGM}, lives here and oversees the Blood Pens. Two {@creature Dread Warrior|TftYP|dread warriors} and eight robed {@creature Zombie||zombies} guard him, and a {@creature black dragon wyrmling} is his personal pet. When the characters first arrive, the dragon has just killed a commoner.

Thuria spends much of his time in seclusion, and relishes the opportunity to fight intruders. If reduced to 20 hit points or fewer, he surrenders and offers two pieces of lore in exchange for his life. He is also willing to give up his treasure and share the attunements of his glyph key, turning over the actual key only under severe threat.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: If Thuria survives an initial encounter with the player characters, he and any surviving allies go on patrol, attacking any intruders in the Doomvault.

entries.name: Garden Beds
entries: Enchantment magic imbues the garden beds. Any living humanoid that spends more than 1 minute here must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious}. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save. On any successful save, the creature is immune to the effect for 24 hours. The creatures here are already immune to this effect.

entries.name: Thuria's Repose
entries: The middle garden bed among the three southernmost beds is full of plants shaped like pieces of furniture. A circular shrub is a resting couch, an angular one is solid enough to use as a desk, and others nearby serve as small chairs.

entries.name: Contact Stone
entries: On the southern wall near Thuria's place of repose is a circle of glowing glyphs that serves as a contact stone.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Thuria wears a gold circlet set with rubies (worth 1,000 gp) and a gold cuff (100 gp). He carries a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell fly} and a {@item Potion of Greater Healing||potion of healing (greater}).
One dread warrior has a {@item +1 longsword}, and each has a gold cuff that matches Thuria's.

In Thuria's "desk" are mundane records of important functions in the Blood Pens. Also within are {@item oil of etherealness} and a {@item potion of poison} disguised as a {@item potion of healing}. A bundle of entwined branches opens like a coffer to reveal 100 pp and a diamond (worth 1,000 gp).

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: Thuria has a glyph key attuned to this zone, the Vermin Halls, the Swine Run, the Hatchery, and the Temples of Turmoil (in the Temples of Extraction sector).

entries.name: White Gate
entries: Beyond the exit to the south, a white gate lies in the corridor that leads to the Hall of Necromancy.

entries.name: Masters' Domain
entries: This sector is the central sanctum of the Red Wizards in charge of the Doomvault.
Locations in the Masters' Domain are identified on map 5.5.

entries.name: Temples of Despair
entries: Although the chambers in this zone are referred to as "temples," they are essentially security rooms designed to destroy the unwary.

entries.name: Doors
entries: All the doors in this zone are locked.

entries.name: Aura
entries: Divine Sense and {@spell detect evil and good} reveal that this zone is thoroughly desecrated.
Glowing pillars brightly light this chamber of white marble. Each pillar is carved in the likeness of a smiling figure with its hands held out, as if ready to accept an offering.
In contrast to the beatific pillars, alcoves around the room contain statues of four-armed gargoyles.

entries.name: Advance Notice
entries: Characters who enter this area feel tranquility despite the gargoyles. If a player expresses doubt about the impression, that player's character can make a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. On a successful check, the character realizes that the emotion is artificial and illusory.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When the characters first enter this area, the eight four-armed gargoyles are true statues. After a door other than a secret door is opened in this area, four {@creature Four-Armed Gargoyle|TftYP|four-armed gargoyles} (as normal {@creature Gargoyle||gargoyles} with 63 hit points and one extra claw attack, for a total of three attacks, with Multiattack) animate and attack. Another four-armed gargoyle animates whenever another such door is opened. This process continues for as long as any gargoyles remain in the alcoves. The gargoyles don't leave the room.

entries.name: Pillars of Light
entries: Seeming to offer a measure of protective power, the pillars have magic designed to prolong the torment of those trapped here. When a creature touches a pillar, the room pulses with light, and that creature gains 5 temporary hit points. Any slain gargoyle disappears when the light pulses, and a new statue appears in an empty alcove. This light pulses spontaneously once an hour, replenishing the gargoyles even if no one is present.

entries.name: Body
entries: Sprawled in front of one alcove, in a location where the characters see it only after entering the room, is the red-robed form of a male human. Vorja, a Red Wizard sent here to face execution, fell to the gargoyles but became stabilized after being left for dead. It takes healing magic or a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check to bring him back to consciousness. He has only 1 hit point unless healing magic was used. Vorja is in no condition to fight, and his loyalty to Thay is tenuous.

If assisted, Vorja can reveal one piece of lore along with descriptions of the Hall of Obedience and the Hall of Necromancy. He knows nothing about this zone. If he is given a glyph key and taken to the black gate, he escapes the Doomvault and joins Syranna's forces.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: The nature of this area means the gargoyles can't be permanently slain.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: A white gate lies in the corridor to the north that connects with the Hatchery. Another white gate is in the eastern passage between this area and the Dark Gardens.

entries.name: 27. Temple of Shadow
entries: A creature near the doors into this area hears a faint moaning that rises in intensity as the creature moves closer to the doors.

A wailing howl erupts from the shadows of this dim chamber, echoing from black marble walls. Dark pillars rise to the ceiling, each exuding shadow that twists in the air like smoke. Alcoves around the room hold statues of four-armed gargoyles shrouded in darkness.

entries.name: Light
entries: Dim light radiates from the pillars and fills the area. Any light source brought into or created in the room radiates only dim light unless it is a spell of 3rd level or higher.

entries.name: Wailing
entries: Pervading the chamber is a horrid wailing that has unnerving effects on non-undead creatures that hear it. Such creatures have disadvantage on melee attack rolls, Strength checks, and Dexterity checks. A character can take an action to make a DC 14 Wisdom check or Charisma check. On a successful check, the character can ignore the effect for 10 minutes.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Shadows swirling around a pillar coalesce into a {@creature wraith} after a door other than a secret door is opened in this area. Another wraith emerges from another pillar each round thereafter, until eight undead have appeared. The undead don't leave the room.

entries.name: Pillars of Shadow
entries: The pillars here are imbued with necromancy magic. An undead creature that touches (or passes through) the pillar gains 5 temporary hit points. A non-undead creature that touches a pillar takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) necrotic damage and 5 ({@dice 1d10}) cold damage. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

entries.name: Black Gate
entries: The space beyond the western false door contains a black gate.

entries.name: Contact Stone
entries: A contact stone is on the wall near the black gate.

The coppery scent of blood hangs heavy in the air in this chamber of dark red marble. Pools of blood are spread across the floor around several dimly glowing red pillars that give off wispy vapors. Statues of four-armed gargoyles, each with mouths and claws dripping blood, stand in alcoves around the chamber.

entries.name: Light
entries: Dim, blood-red light radiates from the pillars and fills the area.

entries.name: Blood
entries: Due to the slick blood on the floor, a creature that moves across the ground at greater than half its normal speed must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The vapor swirling around two of the pillars coalesces into a pair of {@creature Vampiric Mist|MTF|vampiric mists} after a door other than a secret door is opened in this area. Another vampiric mist appears whenever another such door is opened. This process continues until eight of the creatures have manifested.

entries.name: Pillars of Blood
entries: If a living humanoid creature touches a pillar, the part of its body that touched the pillar becomes stuck, and the creature is {@condition restrained}. At the start of each of its turns, the {@condition restrained} creature is drained of blood and must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@dice 1d10}) necrotic damage and have its hit point maximum reduced by the amount of the damage until the creature finishes a long rest. With a successful DC 15 Strength check, a creature can use an action to escape the pillar's hold, or another creature can use an action to pull a victim free.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: Two white gates adjoin {@adventure area 28|TftYP-DiT|1|28. Temple of Blood}. One is in the south passage that leads to the Hall of Obedience, and the other is in the eastern corridor that connects with the Hall of Necromancy.

entries.name: Hall of Obedience
entries: The Red Wizards use the magic of the Hall of Obedience to create zealous followers.

Doors surround a central courtyard here, creating the sense of a monastic sanctuary. Each of the glowing silver pillars that support the ceiling has a set of chains and manacles fastened to it. Thayans hang from four of the pillars, their seemingly dead eyes open wide as if in a state of intense focus.

entries.name: Silver Pillars
entries: Exuding enchantment magic that dulls will and perception, the silver pillars cause any creature in the courtyard to have disadvantage on Wisdom checks and saving throws. Being chained to the pillars causes hypnotic dreams that, after a period of weeks or months, improve combat skill and imbue most creatures with strong devotion to the Red Wizards.

Four {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} chained to the pillars are in an advanced state of entrancement. They can be treated as {@condition unconscious}. If they are slain, a gong sounds in the chamber, alerting the inhabitants of the cells.

entries.name: Cells
entries: Several of the cells are quarters for Thayans who train and work here. Unless otherwise noted, each cell contains rough cots and footlockers that hold worthless personal possessions.

Any commotion in the area, or the sounding of the gong, alerts those in the cells. The Red Wizard emerges 1 round later, and the {@creature Thayan apprentice|TftYP} comes out during the following round. The residents of the other cells take {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds to respond (roll separately for each).
The occupants of the cells are as follows:

{@b Cell A}. A Red Wizard {@creature illusionist|VGM} dwells in this fine chamber with one {@creature Thayan apprentice|TftYP}. The wizard is half asleep. Both have glyph keys attuned to the zone, as well as keys to the C cells. In combat, the apprentice uses an action to open the occupied C cell if able to do so without significant risk.
{@b Cell B}. Two {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} sleep in each of four small rooms. The B cells marked with an asterisk are empty.

{@b Cell C}. The doors to these two cells are locked. Four {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} are held in one of them when it's not their turn to be shackled to the silver pillars. The other C cell is empty.
{@b Cell D}. This cell contains bunks but is empty.

entries.name: Black Gate
entries: The space beyond the secret door in the southeast corner contains a black gate.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: The corridors that exit this area to the north and the east have white gates that connect with the Temples of Despair and the Hall of Necromancy.

An arsenal of weapons and armor hangs from the walls in this broad chamber, the floor of which is stained with blood and black ichor. On the wall between two weapon racks to the east is a contact stone.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Lahnis|TftYP}, a Red Wizard {@creature evoker|VGM}, directs the brutal combat training here. Six {@creature Thayan Warrior|TftYP|Thayan warriors} engage a {@creature dread warrior|TftYP} and seven {@creature Skeleton||skeletons}. {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} orders the whole lot to attack intruders. Because they have been engaged in combat, each creature aside from {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} starts with current hit points equal to half its hit point maximum.

{@creature Lahnis|TftYP} initially stays back in combat, using lower-level spells and trying to assess the characters' motivations. His allegiance to Szass Tam has been flagging. He leans toward supporting the Thayan rebels, but he has not formally joined their ranks. He worries that some of his peers who are loyal to Szass Tam might suspect him.

Aware of Szass Tam's cunning, {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} first assumes the characters are testing his allegiance. Around the second round of combat, or if reduced to half his hit points or fewer, {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} directly asks the characters their purpose and admits a willingness to join the rebels. The characters can sway him with convincing talk and proof that they have overcome other parts of the dungeon. If the characters earn his trust, {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} turns against Szass Tam, having become convinced that the regent's plots will be the undoing of Thay.

He then turns on the Thayans here, whom he knows won't stand down, and helps the characters fight. Afterward, {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} provides two pieces of lore and the attunements on his glyph key, as well as his physical keys. He goes to the gatehouse through the black gate in {@adventure area 29|TftYP-DiT|1|29. Conditioning Court}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Among the weapons here are a {@item +1 battleaxe}, a {@item +1 greatsword}, and a {@item +1 shortbow}. A heavily scarred suit of plate armor here is {@item armor of vulnerability} (your choice of type). In addition, {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} wears a {@item ring of protection}.

entries.name: Keys
entries: {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} carries a glyph key attuned to this zone, the Hall of Necromancy, and the Temples of Despair. He also carries a key that safely opens all the doors in the Temples of Despair, as well as a key to open the C cells in {@adventure area 29|TftYP-DiT|1|29. Conditioning Court}.

entries.name: Development
entries: If {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} joins the rebels, he provides information that decreases the Doomvault's alert level by 1.

entries.name: Hall of Necromancy
entries: Red Wizards practice and refine their darkest magic in the Hall of Necromancy.

entries.name: 31. Undying Laboratory
entries: If {@creature Phaia|TftYP} and Kelson are here (see "Creatures" below), anyone who listens at the doors can hear screaming coming from the other side.

The walls of this black marble mausoleum are lined with hundreds of niches, each holding an ivory urn set with gold, silver, and precious gems. A dozen gray marble tables arrayed across the floor are encrusted with blood and ichor.
In the north side of the room is a black gate.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Phaia|TftYP}, a Red Wizard {@creature necromancer|VGM}, is drawing the soul from {@creature Kelson Darktreader|TftYP}, a male half-elf lying on a stone table farthest from the door the characters use to enter. Kelson is {@condition unconscious} and stable at 0 hit points. {@creature Phaia|TftYP}'s magic is drawing forth from his body a wispy shape that resembles him, and this shape screams in an echoing voice. Strands of energy flow from the shape into the table and from there into other forms in the room.

A {@creature deathlock wight|MTF} on a nearby table is a Red Wizard in the process of being raised as undead. Also nearby, two {@creature Reduced-Threat Wight|TftYP|wights} (see "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" above) are being raised as warrior undead. These wights are only partially animated, so they respond only to {@creature Phaia|TftYP} when she orders an attack. One of them tries to throw an urn at a character each round (+4 to hit, range 10 feet/20 feet; one creature). A hit deals 3 ({@dice 1d6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must make saving throws as noted in the "Urns" section. {@creature Phaia|TftYP} stays for a round or two to assess the party's capabilities and then moves to {@adventure area 32|TftYP-DiT|1|32. Wizards' Court} or uses the black gate in the room.

As a faithful servant of Szass Tam, {@creature Phaia|TftYP} follows the lich lord's philosophy that no magic is too dangerous and no experiment too dark if it promises power. Lawful evil, {@creature Phaia|TftYP} is as opportunistic as she is wicked.

She does anything she can to save herself from death, including using Szass Tam's secrets. She can reveal two pieces of lore and is willing to share her glyph key's attunements. Further, she can teach the characters the ritual that uses this area's magic to return soul-bound undead characters to life.
If she is allowed to do so, {@creature Phaia|TftYP} flees the Doomvault.

entries.name: Aura
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of necromancy on the whole area, signifying the magic that helps in the creation of undead. Divine Sense and {@spell detect evil and good} reveal that this area is desecrated.

entries.name: Stone Tables
entries: These 3-foot-high carved slabs channel the energy of life and undeath. They aid in rituals and spells to create undead.

With the proper knowledge, a creature can use the stone tables to transform a soul-bound character back into a normal creature. Doing so requires the aid of a Red Wizard or explicit written instruction, such as the scroll in {@creature Lahnis|TftYP}'s room in {@adventure area 32|TftYP-DiT|1|32. Wizards' Court}. The ritual takes 20 minutes and requires a spellcaster to make a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. The spellcaster must also expend a 3rd-level spell slot. On a successful check, the soul-bound creature returns to normal with all of its Hit Dice expended. On a failed check, the spell slot is expended but the creature remains soul bound.

entries.name: Urns
entries: The urns are magic and worthless but clever fakes that appear valuable, requiring a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern the truth. Any non-undead creature that touches an urn must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution or Wisdom saving throw (creature's choice) or take 10 ({@dice 3d6}) necrotic damage and become {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save. If this damage reduces a creature to 0 hit points, the creature dies and turns to dust.

entries.name: Kelson
entries: Despite his ordeal, {@creature Kelson Darktreader|TftYP} can be restored to health through normal means, although he is in no condition to help. He thanks the characters for saving him and offers two pieces of lore. He asks for a glyph key and goes to the gatehouse to recuperate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Phaia|TftYP} carries a {@item +1 dagger}, a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell darkvision}, and a {@item potion of water breathing}.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: {@creature Phaia|TftYP} has a glyph key attuned to this zone and the Temples of Oppression (in the Temples of Extraction sector).

entries.name: White Gates
entries: The corridor that leads west has a white gate that connects with the Temples of Despair. In the northern leg of the corridor to the east is another white gate that leads to the Dark Gardens.

A stepped monument of gray marble shot through with red dominates an open courtyard surrounded by closed doors. Blue light shines from the top of the monument. The air around it hums with power, its vibration overwhelming other sensations. Red Wizards and other Thayans kneel on the lower two tiers, eyes fixed on the monument.

entries.name: Stepped Monument
entries: The monument amplifies magic in the courtyard, but those in the area have trouble with physical sensations and tasks, and they have disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws. Meditating on the monument causes hypnotic dreams that, after a period of weeks or months, improve spellcasting capabilities and imbue most creatures with strong devotion to the Red Wizards.
Each tier of the monument is 5 feet high, and clambering onto it requires 5 extra feet of movement.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature Thayan Apprentice|TftYP|Thayan apprentices} kneel on the lower tier of the monument. The Thayans attack intruders.

entries.name: Cells
entries: The cells around the perimeter of the court (rooms labeled A through D on the map) are quarters for Thayans who train and work here. Unless otherwise noted, each cell contains rough cots and footlockers holding worthless personal possessions. Cells marked with an asterisk on the map are empty.
Combat in the courtyard alerts the inhabitants of the cells. They take {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds to respond (roll for each one):

{@b Cell A}. {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} (see {@adventure area 30|TftYP-DiT|1|30. Training Floor}) uses these quarters, which contain a fine bed, a footlocker, and a desk. Searching the area uncovers one written piece of lore, as well as a {@item tome of the stilled tongue} and six {@item Spell Scroll||spell scrolls} (two each of {@spell detect magic}, {@spell identify}, and {@spell remove curse}). {@creature Lahnis|TftYP} also has a scroll describing the ritual used to turn soul-bound undead back into non-undead creatures in {@adventure area 31|TftYP-DiT|1|31. Undying Laboratory}.
{@b Cell B}. One Red Wizard {@creature evoker|VGM} sleeps here.
{@b Cell C}. One {@creature Thayan apprentice|TftYP} sleeps here.
{@b Cell D}. Each of these two rooms is a library. An hour spent examining a library's contents turns up two pieces of lore.

entries.name: Contact Stone
entries: Atop the monument is a circle of glowing glyphs that serves as a contact stone.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: The Red Wizard in cell B has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: Two white gates separate {@adventure area 32|TftYP-DiT|1|32. Wizards' Court} from other zones. The gate in the corridor to the west leads to the Hall of Obedience. Beyond the doors to the south is a gate that connects with the Dread Legion Outpost.

entries.name: Dread Legion Outpost
entries: The Dread Legion, Thay's army, maintains a full company in the Doomvault.
Glowing crystals set into the walls and floors light a rough stone cavern. To the south is a black gate.

entries.name: Blue Crystals
entries: The blue crystals brightly light the area.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One {@creature Thayan warrior|TftYP}, five {@creature Gnoll||gnolls}, and five {@creature Orc||orcs} attack intruders on sight.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: The {@creature Thayan warrior|TftYP} has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: 34. Shard Cavern
entries: This cavern has no light.

The walls and ceiling of this rough cavern are a mass of rock spines, the floor covered with rock dust and shards. A path has been worn through the rubble, winding between double doors to the west and a rough flight of stairs rising to the larger and lit open space to the east.

entries.name: Path
entries: Except on the path, the ground in the room is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Shard Storm Trap
entries: Transmutation magic infuses the room. Any creature that spends more than 1 round in this area triggers the trap. When the trap triggers, each creature in the room who isn't wearing a Thayan uniform must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@dice 4d6}) piercing damage from flying shards on a failed save, or only half as much damage on a successful one. This effect repeats every round until the room is empty, when the trap resets.
The path becomes {@quickref difficult terrain||3}, and if the creatures in areas 33 and 35 can hear the trap go off, the guards have warning that intruders are in the area.

entries.name: Stone Wall
entries: A rough stone wall separates the lower cavern of {@adventure area 34|TftYP-DiT|1|34. Shard Cavern} from the higher finished chamber of {@adventure area 35|TftYP-DiT|1|35. Dread Legion Barracks}. The wall is 15 feet high.

entries.name: 35. Dread Legion Barracks
entries: The light in this room can be seen from {@adventure area 34|TftYP-DiT|1|34. Shard Cavern}. Unless the creatures here have a reason to be quiet, they are talking loudly.
Three bonfires light this vast chamber, their smoke rising to vent through cracks in the ceiling. Scattered bedding and the stench of unwashed humanoids suggest that many creatures might dwell here.
In the east, on the wall between two oversized bedrolls, is a contact stone.

entries.name: Bonfires
entries: Large fires brightly light this area. A creature that enters a bonfire for the first time on a turn, or starts its turn in a fire, takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) fire damage.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Resting in this chamber are a {@creature Thayan warrior|TftYP} and a Dread Legion squad made up of five {@creature Orc||orcs} and five {@creature Gnoll||gnolls}. A {@creature troll} is on post here to keep the other legionnaires in line.

entries.name: Stone Wall
entries: See {@adventure area 34|TftYP-DiT|1|34. Shard Cavern}.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: The Dread Legion patrols throughout the Doomvault. If a squad resting in the barracks is slain, an identical squad arrives here within 1 hour.

entries.name: Glyph Keys
entries: The {@creature Thayan warrior|TftYP} has a glyph key attuned to every zone in this sector. The troll has a glyph key attuned to this zone.

entries.name: White Gates
entries: A white gate is located in the corridor to the south, leading to the Warren of Eyes. Another white gate is in the passage to the north that connects with the Hall of Necromancy.

entries.name: Far Realm Cysts
entries: The influence of the Far Realm has warped a portion of the Doomvault, where several star-shaped chambers have been turned into a weird mix of worked stone and glistening walls. Unless otherwise noted, these caverns are dark.
Locations in the Far Realm Cysts are identified on map 5.6.

entries.name: Lake of Madness
entries: An aboleth dwells in a watery crevasse, seething at its imprisonment and hungry to enslave the living.

entries.name: 36. Dark Water
entries: Water can be heard rippling in this dark area before the characters arrive.

The walls of this cavern are the same dark shade of blue as the pool of water that fills the center of the area. Ripples spread across the surface as if the water has been recently disturbed. Around the cavern, narrow alcoves hold enormous globes of blue liquid suspended in the air.
In the west side of the room is a black gate, and on the wall near it is a contact stone.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One {@creature reduced-threat aboleth|TftYP} (see "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" above) dwells deep in the pool. Within this room, the aboleth can use the water globes (see "Water Globes" below) to move around.

The aboleth's ordeal in the Doomvault has weakened it, making it a reduced threat. In addition, its hatred of the Red Wizards makes the aboleth a potential ally. With a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, or another successful and appropriate check, a character can convince the aboleth to stand down and negotiate. In exchange for sparing the characters, the aboleth demands to be freed and given a glyph key.

entries.name: Pool
entries: Over 350 feet deep, this pool has sheer sides that drop to its bottom. The water within 10 feet of the surface is a lightly obscured area, and deeper water is heavily obscured.

entries.name: Water Globes
entries: Floating 5 feet above the floor, these magic water globes are 15 feet in diameter. Red Wizards use them to hold aquatic creatures for transport through the black gates.

As an action, a creature that is within 5 feet of a globe and has an Intelligence score of 10 or higher can take control of the globe by succeeding on a DC 10 Intelligence check. As part of its movement and with a successful DC 10 Intelligence check, the controller can direct the globe to move with it, remaining within 5 feet of the controller. A globe's controller can enter and leave the globe at will. The controller can maintain control of the globe while within 100 feet of it. Another creature that qualifies as a controller can gain control of a globe by winning a contest of Intelligence checks against the current controller.

A creature that touches a globe but isn't its controller must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be drawn into the globe and unable to pass back through its boundary. As an action, a trapped creature can free itself with a successful DC 15 Intelligence check. Also as an action, a globe's controller can release a trapped creature with a successful DC 10 Intelligence check. A creature inside a globe has half cover against effects that originate outside the globe. While inside a globe, a trapped creature can't contest for control of the globe.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: If the characters free the aboleth, it wanders the dungeon and attacks anyone it runs across.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: A white gate lies in the east–west corridor between this area and the Warren of Eyes.

entries.name: Light
entries: The dim light that fills the chamber can be seen before the room can.
Dim light dances in the air, shimmering through the colors of the rainbow, gently lighting the walls of this cavern. A few piles of bones and scraps of gear litter the floor.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The shimmering light here has affected two {@creature Wight||wights}, two {@creature Dread Warrior|TftYP|dread warriors}, and six {@creature Zombie||zombies}. They attack if the trap's effect on them ends.

entries.name: Compelling Light Trap
entries: Any creature that sees the magical light while within this area must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or enter the cavern and stand there while ignoring all other stimuli. When an affected creature takes damage, the creature can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a successful save. Any non-undead creature that ends its turn in the lighted room takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) necrotic damage.
A {@spell dispel magic} spell suppresses the light's effect for 10 minutes. Any spell that overwhelms or blocks the light also suppresses it in the spell's area for the duration of the spell.

entries.name: Glyph Key
entries: One of the dread warriors has a glyph key attuned to the Forest of Death.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: A white gate lies at the foot of the stairs leading west toward the Forest of Death.

entries.name: Warren of Eyes
entries: {@creature Reduced-Threat Beholder|TftYP|Thaxalia}, a beholder, has been summoned and imprisoned here.

entries.name: Light
entries: This zone is bathed in a weird green glow that provides dim illumination.

entries.name: 38. Sinkhole Cavern

entries: This rough cavern has an uneven floor with open holes in it. In the east, on a spar of rock, is a contact stone.
If the characters come from the north, add the following.
Southwest of the doors is an alcove that contains a black gate.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Eight {@creature Zombie||zombies} and two {@creature Ogre Zombie||ogre zombies} attack any intruders. Any combat warns {@creature Reduced-Threat Beholder|TftYP|Thaxalia} ({@adventure area 39|TftYP-DiT|1|39. Beholder's Domain}) of the approach of intruders.

entries.name: Sinkholes
entries: These open sinkholes are 5 feet across and 10 feet deep. A creature that falls into a sinkhole is {@condition restrained} in the narrow bottom. It takes a successful DC 13 Strength check or Dexterity check to work free, and a Small creature has advantage on this check. It's then an easy matter to climb out of the sinkhole.

entries.name: White Gate
entries: The passage that leads west has a white gate that connects with the Lake of Madness.
Hundreds of unblinking eyes stare into this room from long walls of glistening green stone. The floor of this chamber is covered with viscous slime that drips from four stalagmites.

entries.name: Beholder
entries: {@creature Reduced-Threat Beholder|TftYP|Thaxalia}, a reduced-threat {@creature beholder} (see "{@adventure Reduced-Threat Monsters|TftYP-DiT|1|Reduced-Threat Monsters}" above) crippled by Thayan magic, floats near the ceiling, trying to remain unnoticed while intruders enter. Thaxalia's central eye and two of its eyestalks have been maimed by the Red Wizards, rendering those eye rays (death ray and disintegration) powerless. If it has warning or is reduced to 50 hit points or fewer, it withdraws to {@adventure area 40|TftYP-DiT|1|40. Slime Slaves}, leaving its spawn to deal with the threat.

After only 2 rounds, Thaxalia's hatred for the Red Wizards inspires the beholder to question the characters' purpose in the dungeon. If they reveal their goals, the beholder suggests an alliance, extolling its plans for revenge.

Fearing Thaxalia's ability to wreak havoc if it escapes this zone, the Red Wizards cursed the beholder with the inability to use glyph keys. Thaxalia doesn't know the solution, but a {@spell remove curse} spell can eliminate the prohibition. The beholder then takes a glyph key from the wight in {@adventure area 40|TftYP-DiT|1|40. Slime Slaves} and asks the characters to provide it with more attunements. If refused, it becomes hostile and uses its powers to compel the characters to give it more attunements.

entries.name: Beholder Spawn
entries: Clinging to the cavern walls by the hundreds, between this world and the Far Realm, are the manifestations of beholder spawn. These spawn aren't independent creatures, but they can project weak eye rays that function as an area hazard. At the start of each of its turns, any creature other than Thaxalia in the cavern must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or suffer one of the following effects, rolled randomly.

rows: {@i Charm}. For its turn, the target moves toward its nearest ally and attacks with a weapon or a cantrip. The target can't check for danger as it moves.
{@i Telekinesis}. The target is pushed 5 feet in a random direction and falls {@condition prone}.
{@i Slow}. Until the start of its next turn, the target's speed is reduced by 15 feet, and others make attack rolls against the target with advantage.
{@i Sleep}. The target falls {@condition unconscious} until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Slime
entries: Covering the rough floor is 1 foot of thick slime, which is {@quickref difficult terrain||3} and covers several hidden sinkholes. Any creature that starts its turn {@condition prone} in or submerged in the slime takes 4 ({@dice 1d8}) poison damage.

entries.name: Sinkholes
entries: These open sinkholes are 5 feet across and 10 feet deep, and they are filled with slime. While moving near a sinkhole, a character who succeeds on a DC 20 {@skill Perception} check notices the hazard due to the flow of slime in and around it. A creature that falls into a sinkhole is {@condition restrained} in the narrow bottom and submerged in slime, unable to breathe. It takes a successful DC 15 Strength check or Dexterity check to work free, and a Small creature has advantage on this check. It then takes a successful DC 10 Strength check to climb out of the sinkhole.

entries.name: Stalagmites
entries: These 10-foot-diameter spires of rock rise 20 feet above the floor and exude the otherworldly slime. Their sides are slick and smooth, difficult to climb.

entries.name: Dungeon State
entries: If freed and given a glyph key, Thaxalia allows the characters free passage through this area. While Thaxalia is free in the Doomvault, it prefers to attack Thayans. If encountered again, the beholder might help the characters, given incentives.
The beholder spawn in this area are no longer a threat to those who freed Thaxalia. If Thaxalia is destroyed, the beholder spawn here disappear.

entries.name: 40. Slime Slaves

entries: Viscous slime covers this chamber. Rough stone steps lead up and out.

If {@creature Reduced-Threat Beholder|TftYP|Thaxalia} left {@adventure area 39|TftYP-DiT|1|39. Beholder's Domain}, the beholder is in this location. It has been picking off Thayan patrols here. Amid the slime are five bodies: two of wights and three of Thayan warriors.

entries.name: Slime
